Article Title: IIM-C wins NTPC Electron Quiz 2025
Article Text: NEW DELHI: IIM-Calcutta walked away with the winner's award as well as the second runner-up prize in NTPC Electron Quiz-2025, while FMS-Delhi was the first runner-up, as the month-long quizzing carnival concluded on Feb 28.The champion team of Piyus Kedia and Amartya Saha showcased exceptional analytical and problem-solving skills , taking home a cash prize of Rs 50,000. The first runner-up team comprising Ankita Shandilya and Shashank Tyagi received a cheque of Rs 30,000, while the second runner-up team of Komal Vasudeva and Araya Arun received Rs 20,000. More than 700 teams participated in this annual quiz fest held across nine locations - Ranchi, Patna, Lucknow, Raipur, Hyderabad, Mumbai, Chennai, Kolkata and Noida.After nine regional and three semifinal rounds, six teams qualified for the grand finale, held at NTPC Power Management Institute in Noida. NTPC's director (HR), Anil Kumar Jadli, congratulated all the participants for their exceptional display of critical thinking and competitive spirit. NTPC Electron Quiz has been nurturing young talents and cultivating a platform for knowledge sharing for the last two decades, he said.
Article Summary: More than 700 teams participated in NTPC Electron Quiz-2025. IIM-Calcutta walked away with the winner's award as well as the second runner-up prize. The month- long quizzing carnival concluded on Feb 28.

Article Title: 'Boxers shouldn't suffer': Nikhat Zareen and Lovlina Borgohain demand end to impasse
Article Text:
Nikhat Zareen and Lovlina Borgohain

No roadmap since Paris Olympics has left them 'clueless'

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

'IOA's decision undermines BFI's autonomy'

NEW DELHI: Echoing the sentiment of their fellow boxers, two of India's premier women boxers — Nikhat Zareen and Lovlina Borgohain — have called for expeditious elections in the Boxing Federation of India (BFI) and a swift resolution of the deadlock between the sport's governing body and Indian Olympic Association (IOA) over the formation of an ad-hoc committee. The boxers asserted that the ongoing stalemate has impacted their training regimen for important forthcoming championships.Two-time world champion Nikhat said that the boxers are "clueless" about their future, having been deprived of exposure trips and international competitions since the Paris Olympics in July-Aug last year. The 28-year-old from Nizamabad highlighted the federation's inability to conduct the elite women's Nationals, national camp and facilitate participation in the Strandja Memorial meet in Sofia."Boxers shouldn't suffer because of the BFI's election issue. We don't know what the future has in store for us. All I have been doing is training at the Army Sports Institute (ASI) in Pune since Jan this year," Nikhat told TOI, "This is an important year, with the World boxing championships in Liverpool in Sep and then the World Cup season finals in Nov in India. We (boxers) need certain clarity about the national camp, exposure trips and competitions abroad. We missed the Strandja meet where India has been a regular participant."I would like the BFI to conduct its elections at the earliest, so that the new set of office-bearers can prepare the future roadmap, and the things can be streamlined," she added.Lovlina, the Tokyo Games bronze medallist, asserted that boxers should not bear consequences for circumstances beyond their control. "As a boxer, our responsibility is to train well, represent the country and secure medals. All we require is a proper structure. There's a necessity to devise a comprehensive strategy regarding our training and competition for the future tournaments. Since the Paris Games, nothing substantial has happened in Indian boxing. It's time the boxers went out and competed," the three-time World Championships medallist stated.Nikhat, who resumed training after a three-month long injury lay-off following the Olympics, added that the administrative impasse has left the boxers a "confused lot", with respect on whose instructions to follow – BFI or the ad-hoc panel."The BFI is saying something, ad-hoc committee is saying something. There are factions within the federation. Then, I suppose, there's a court case going on. I don't know what to do (in this situation). The only good news is that the IOC has granted (provisional) recognition to World Boxing."World Boxing president Boris van der Vorst has written to IOA president PT Usha, stating that the formation of the ad-hoc committee by the latter "undermines the BFI's autonomy" and the decision is "not fully justifiable".Vorst said that the unfortunate situation in India "is not a fruit of bad faith and (has been) influenced by those who have placed boxing in the difficult position to which World Boxing has fought so hard to crawl out of".
Article Summary: Nikhat Zareen and Lovlina Borgohain have called for expeditious elections in the Boxing Federation of India (BFI) They also want a swift resolution of the deadlock between the sport's governing body and Indian Olympic Association (IOA) over the formation of an ad-hoc committee. The boxers asserted that the ongoing stalemate has impacted their training regimen for important championships.

Article Title: Mason Taylor proved at the NFL Combine he’s better than most tight ends in this draft

Mason Taylor walked into the offseason as a second or third-round prospect. That might not be the case anymore. The LSU tight end has been stacking wins—first at the Reese’s Senior Bowl, where his blocking and receiving skills had scouts paying attention, and now at the NFL Combine, where he put on a clinic during on-field drills.Taylor didn’t participate in testing, but that didn’t matter. He looked sharper than anyone else in the drills, turning heads and forcing analysts to reconsider where he stands in this tight-end class.Harold Fannin Jr., Gunnar Helm, and Terrance Ferguson came into the Combine ranked ahead of Mason Taylor on some draft boards. That changed once the drills started.Rich Eisen and Daniel Jeremiah couldn’t stop talking about how smooth Taylor looked running the gauntlet drill. He made it look routine. Effortless.ESPN draft analyst Matt Miller didn’t hold back either.NFL draft analyst Jordan Reid also noted how comfortable Taylor looked, and at this point, the buzz is undeniable—Taylor belongs in the top tier of this class.Right now, most draft analysts have Tyler Warren and Colston Loveland ranked ahead of Mason Taylor. That’s mostly because those two were the focal points of their offenses. Taylor wasn’t. LSU’s offense revolved around its wide receivers, which means his numbers don’t tell the full story.But here’s what the numbers won’t show: Taylor is the best blocking tight end in this draft class. Period. He handles defenders like a lineman and still moves like a receiver.That’s a skill NFL teams value. Some of the best tight ends in the league aren’t just receivers—they’re complete players who can protect the quarterback and open up the run game. Taylor fits that mold better than anyone in this draft.Mason Taylor still has one more chance to prove himself before the draft. LSU’s Pro Day is coming up, and this time, he’ll participate in full testing. A solid 40-yard dash and strong athletic numbers could erase any doubt about his first-round potential.He doesn’t have the concerns that held back his father, Jason Taylor, or his uncle, Zach Thomas, when they were entering the league. He’s not undersized. He’s not overlooked. But he still carries the same mentality—nothing is guaranteed.Taylor said at the Combine.He’s handled every opportunity perfectly so far. One more, and Mason Taylor could hear his name called on Day 1 of the NFL Draft.
Article Summary: Mason Taylor put on a clinic during on-field drills at the NFL Combine. He looked sharper than anyone else in the drills, turning heads and forcing analysts to reconsider where he stands in this tight-end class. The LSU tight end still has one more chance to prove himself before the draft.

Article Title: Ranji Trophy Final: Kerala trail Vidarbha despite Sachin Baby's knock
Article Text:
Sachin Baby (BCCI Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

BRIEF SCORES:

NAGPUR: Sachin Baby sunk to his knees after having miscued the slog sweep. Playing his 100th first-class game, the Kerala skipper had till then been concentration personified for 235 balls. That ill-fated shot on Day Three of the Ranji Trophy final at Jamtha Stadium on Friday, however, allowed Vidarbha the way back into the game. Just two short of his century, and with Kerala 56 adrift of Vidarbha's first-innings total, Baby (98; 235b, 10x4) attempted the uncharacteristic shot off left-arm spinner Parth Rekhade. He couldn't connect properly, and Karun Nair at deep midwicket promptly pouched the skier.As the Vidarbha players danced in celebration, Baby remained on his knees, the costly error of judgement having sunk in.After Baby's dismissal, Jalaj Saxena and the tail batted for 15.1 overs, scoring just 18 runs as Kerala were dismissed for 342. In between, Vidarbha's Harsh Dubey trapped Nidheesh MD LBW to enter the record books as the man to take the most wickets in a Ranji Trophy season.“Baby played a good knock. I think his plan was to hold one end. But a brain-fade moment resulted in his wicket. Definitely, that was a turning point for us as he was building a good partnership with Jalaj Saxena. Our plan was to stop the runs and wait for a bad shot,” Dubey said about Baby's dismissal.The end of Day Three saw Vidarbha earn a slender 37-run lead. The final, though, is far from over. Having Jalaj Saxena and Aditya Sarvate, spinners of high repute, Kerala will still be harbouring thoughts of plotting a Vidarbha collapse on a pitch assisting tweakers.Friday's action was all about two milestone men — Baby and Dubey — toiling hard under the harsh sun. Baby started the day with a boundary. Aditya Sarwate, who led the Kerala charge the other day, though, looked a bit edgy. Sarwate's 79-run knock (185b;10x4) ended when a Harsh Dubey ball rose sharply to hit the shoulder of his bat and lobbed up to close in fielder Danish Malewar.Vidarbha 379 in 123.1 overs lead Kerala (overnight 131/3 in 39 overs) 342 in 125 overs (Sachin Baby 98, Aditya Sarvate 79, Ahammed Imran 37, Mohammed Azharuddeen 34, Jalaj Saxena 28; Parth Rekhade 3-65, Harsh Dubey 3-88, Darshan Nalkande 3-52, Yash Thakur 1-83) by 37 runs.
Article Summary: Vidarbha earn a slender 37-run lead at the end of Day Three of the Ranji Trophy final at Jamtha Stadium. Sachin Baby was two short of his century when he miscued a slog sweep. The Kerala skipper had till then been concentration personified for 235 balls.

Article Title: "I’m growing each day": Lewis Hamilton fires back at critics, says their doubts only fuel his drive for success
Article Text:
Credit: Getty Images

Lewis Hamilton Embraces Criticism as Fuel for Ferrari Challenge



Lewis Hamilton has never been one to shy away from criticism. Instead, he has used it as a driving force to push himself forward. The seven-time world champion, now embarking on a fresh chapter with Ferrari , has made it clear that negative remarks, including those from former F1 figures like Eddie Jordan and Bernie Ecclestone, do not shake his resolve. On the final day of pre-season testing in Bahrain, Hamilton reiterated that such critiques only add to his motivation.Throughout his illustrious career, Hamilton has been no stranger to scrutiny. However, he remains unbothered, focusing instead on his personal growth and pursuit of excellence. "In our sport, criticism is something that everyone receives," he acknowledged. "I have probably received a lot more of it perhaps throughout my career but I just keep my head down, doing what I’m doing. I know that I’m growing each day, I’m bound to make mistakes, I’m only human but one thing that I’m proud of is I have a drive, a focus."His ability to acknowledge mistakes and use setbacks as lessons has been a hallmark of his success. "I’m able to admit when I’m wrong and I know that tomorrow I will work to be better and it really doesn’t matter to me some of the comments that have come up over my career... I use that as fuel," he added. This mindset will be crucial as he steps into a new era with Ferrari, leaving behind a 12-year tenure with Mercedes that saw him clinch six drivers' championships.Hamilton’s switch to Ferrari has generated immense anticipation, not just among fans but within the F1 paddock as well. The move comes at a time when Mercedes has struggled to adapt to the post-2022 regulations, while Red Bull, McLaren, and Ferrari have closed the gap at the front. Despite the challenges, Hamilton is approaching his debut season with the Italian team with renewed energy and confidence.Following the conclusion of three days of pre-season testing, Hamilton expressed a strong sense of optimism about the SF25. His gut feeling about the car and his new team’s operations is overwhelmingly positive. "I would say this is the most positive feeling that I’ve had in a long time," he admitted. "I feel like in this period of time we’ve built a really good foundation but everyone, you know these guys out there, look really, really quick, really competitive."While the true pecking order will only be revealed once the racing begins, Hamilton remains encouraged by the hard work of his Ferrari colleagues. "It looks very very close. We won’t know obviously until next week truly, exactly where we stand but we know that we’ve got work to do and everyone is just heads down and I’ve been really inspired and really encouraged by my colleagues," he stated.Also Read: Lewis Hamilton responds with class to Eddie Jordan's bold claim on Ferrari move being “suicidal” With the new season on the horizon, Hamilton’s hunger for an eighth world championship remains as strong as ever. His ability to channel criticism into motivation, coupled with his initial confidence in Ferrari’s potential, sets the stage for an intriguing and potentially historic campaign.
Article Summary: Lewis Hamilton has never been one to shy away from criticism. The seven-time world champion has used it as a driving force to push himself forward. Hamilton left Mercedes at the end of last season to join Ferrari. The Briton is optimistic about his debut season with the Italian team.

Article Title: 2nd ODI: Virat Kohli's in, but who's out? Selection dilemma as India look to seal series against England
Article Text:
Virat Kohli during a practice session. (PTI Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

'It’s a slightly two-paced pitch': Harshit Rana after claiming three-wicket haul on ODI debut

CUTTACK: One look at the stands on Saturday evening at the Barabati Stadium , and one could have been forgiven for mistaking it for match day instead of match eve.The Odisha Cricket Association 's (OCA) decision to open part of the stands for fans to watch India train, for free, ahead of the crucial second ODI against England here was a hit, with the stadium nearly half full.The loudest cheers from the 20,000-plus crowd were reserved for the man who missed the first ODI in Nagpur with a sore right knee — Virat Kohli Saturday's nets, however, suggested Kohli was not going to sit out another game. One of the fittest cricketers around, the former India captain last missed a match — before the Nagpur ODI — more than three years ago, the Johannesburg Test against South Africa in Jan 2022. Fit and raring to go, the star batter was the first to hit the nets and batted for nearly an hour before leaving the ground first, shouldering his cricket coffin.While England completely skipped Saturday's practice, many India players also skipped the optional session, including last-match hero Shreyas Iyer , vice-captain Shubman Gill , debutant Harshit Rana, comeback man Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Axar Patel."Virat Kohli is fit to play. He has come for practice and is good to go," batting coach Sitanshu Kotak said during the prematch media interaction.With a fit-again Kohli back in the playing XI, India will face a selection dilemma as they prepare to tick all the boxes ahead of the Champions Trophy and seal the series before going to Ahmedabad.Will Iyer lose his place to Kohli if the team management decides to continue with Yashasvi Jaiswal to keep the left-right opening combination going with captain Rohit Sharma ? Kotak, however, bypassed any queries on who should make way for Kohli on Sunday."I think that's what the head coach and captain can talk about. But yes, definitely a lefty-righty combination is there. But I would say that question is not something which I would like to answer, to be very honest," was Kotak's diplomatic answer.Rohit's form will certainly also be a concern for the side, no matter how the management tries to brush aside any doubts regarding his continuous run of poor form. Rohit, incidentally, got out after scoring only two runs in the first ODI of this series.Rohit coming back into form will certainly be a big boost for the hosts ahead of the ICC event starting on Feb 19. The track looks a belter and could well be the right platform for the ‘Hitman' to get some much-needed runs under his belt.Meanwhile, KL Rahul is likely to get another look-in as the wicketkeeper-batter ahead of Rishabh Pant, who batted for long in the nets. However, left-arm pacer Arshdeep Singh bowled long spells during the practice session and could replace Shami, who might be rested to manage his workload following a long injury layoff.Although dew factor is unlikely to come into play here, batting second will be the preferred choice, as chasing teams have won 12 out of the 19 ODIs played here over the years.

England completely skipped Saturday's practice, but many India players also skipped the optional session.
